form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Application by Lawful Permanent Resident for New Alien Registration Receipt Card, GPO: 1988 O – 206–553

full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/31/2023 U.S. Department of Justice Application by Lawful Permanent Resident Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) for New Alien Registration Receipt Card Instructions Read the instructions carefully. If you do not follow the instructions, we may have to return your application, which may delay final action. 1. Who can file? 5. What is the fee? You may file this form only if If you check (a) or (b) of item 18 "Reason for New Card," you are a lawful permanent resident of the United States you must pay $15.00 to file this form. The fee will not be refunded, whether the application is approved or not. and DO NOT MAIL CASH. All checks or money orders, whether you need a new card. U.S. or foreign, must be payable in U.S. currency at a finan- cial institution in the United States. When a check is drawn 2. What documents do you need? on the account of a person other than yourself, write your A. If you have your old card, you must give it to INS with name on the face of the check. If the check is not honored, this application. INS will charge you $5.00. E. Give the INS two color photographs of yourself taken Pay by check or money order in the exact amount. Make within 30 days of the date of this application. These the check or money order payable to "Immigration and photos must have a white background. They must be Naturalization Service." However, glossy, un-retouched, and not mounted. The dimension of the facial image must be about 1 inch from the chin to A. if you live in Guam: Make the check or money order the top of hair; your face should be in 3/4 frontal view, payable to "Treasurer, Guam", or showing the right side of the face with the right ear visible. B. if you live in the U.S. Virgin Islands: Make the check or money order payable to "Commission of Finance of the Using pencil or felt pen, lightly print your name (and Virgin Islands" Alien Registration Number, if you know it) on the back of each photograph. 6. What are the penalties for submitting false information? 3. How should you prepare this form? Title 18, United States Code, Section 1001 states that A. Type or print legibly in ink. whoever willfully and knowingly falsifies a material fact, B. If you need extra space to complete any item, attach a makes a false statement, or makes use of a false document continuation sheet, indicate the item number, and date will be fined up to $10,000 or imprisoned up to five years, and sign each sheet. or both. C. Answer all questions fully and accurately. If any item does not apply, please write "N/A." 7. What is our authority for collecting this information? We request the information on this form to carry out the im- 4. Where should you file this form? migration laws contained in Title 8, United States Code A. If you are in the United States, take this application form 1304(c). We need this information to determine whether a in person to the INS office having jurisdiction over your person is eligible for immigration benefits. The information place of residence. you provide may also be disclosed to other federal, state, local, and foreign law enforcement and regulatory agencies B. If you are outside the United States, take this application during the course of the investigation required by this form in person to the United States consulate or INS Service. You do not have to give this information. However, office that has jurisdiction over the place where you are if you refuse to give some or all of it, your application may now living. be denied. LEB 01 1001 It is not possible to cover all the conditions for eligibility or to give instructions for every situation. If you have carefully read all the instructions and still have questions, please contact your nearest INS office.
